instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Did I kill the CPU
threads.message:
Hi, 

Had some sensor issues with this one so I decided to replace <CHIP>U5800</CHIP>. After I replaced it, it doesn't boot anymore. I'm guessing I fried the CPU, which is right on the other side of the board. Any suggestions?

Cheers, Rick

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Did I kill the CPU
threads.message: first things first. check the surrounding area where u worked. Then go back to the basics check power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Did I kill the CPU
threads.message: All the S0 voltages are present but I'm getting no chime and no video. Any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Did I kill the CPU
threads.message: Probably fucked it, take <CHIP>U5800</CHIP> off and pray it will work again. If not CPU may be dead or balls got crushed/separated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Did I kill the CPU
threads.message: Hmmm... Any suggestions for when I try this next time? So replacing <CHIP>U5800</CHIP> without screwing up the CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Did I kill the CPU
threads.message: Use less heat, practice more. There is no golden tip for this. Also a dead <CHIP>U5800</CHIP> never happens, usually something else on the data bus is messing things up. Corrosion on connectors and SMC are the most likely.
